Graphical abstract By using the co-precipitation technique, we successfully synthesized spherical Na3(VOPO4)2F cathode and revealed the embedding mechanism of NH4 +/H3O+ cations into material lattice, as well as their removal through facile heat treatment. The aqueous preparation of Na3(VOPO4)2F cathode material with low cost and good structural stability has attracted extensive attention for advancing sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). However, the inclusive heterogeneous cations incorporated into the material lattice, dominated by coordination chemistry, are always overlooked. Herein, the embroiled NH4 +/H3O+ cations in the Na3(VOPO4)2F lattice have been first disclosed during aqueous co-precipitation. It involves the electrostatic interactions between hydrogen protons (NH4 +/H3O+) and electronegative oxygen atoms (V=O and V–O–P groups), which induces the terrible Na+-storage performance, as demonstrated by multiple characterizations. Followingly, the very-facile operation, i.e. heat treatment, has been raised to remove NH4 +/H3O+ cations and then achieved high-performance Na3(VOPO4)2F. Therefore, the Na3(VOPO4)2F||Na cell contributes to the significantly improved discharge capacity (129.7 mAh g−1) and voltage plateau from 3.63 to 3.87 V (vs. Na/Na+) at 0.2 C. The ultrahigh capacity retentions of 93.7% and 76.7% after 1000 and 3500 cycles at 1 and 20 C rates under 25 °C are harvested, respectively, as well as high/low-temperature performances and rate capability. Eventually, the as-assembled Na3(VOPO4)2F||hard carbon full-cell delivers excellent long-term cycling stability over 1000 cycles with 97.5% retention at 3 C. These emphasize the high-efficacy synthesis of Na3(VOPO4)2F and provide insights into the aqueous co-precipitation for the development of materials used in SIBs. Keywords Sodium-ion battery Aqueous co-precipitation Na3(VOPO4)2F Heat treatment, Electrostatic interactions 1 Introduction With the advancement and applications of electrochemical technology, the dilemma of limited lithium resources has aroused great interest in the development of cost-effective and high-performance sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) for future energy storage [1,2]. Thereinto, NASICON-type phosphates with fluoro-substitution chemistry (e.g. sodium vanadium fluorophosphate, Na3(VOPO4)2F (abbreviated as NVOPF)) pave the way for exploring the potential cathode materials for SIBs-based stationary storage systems due to their higher theoretical discharge specific capacity (∼130 mAh g−1) and output voltage (>3.8 V, vs. Na/Na+) as compared with the layered transition metal oxides and Prussian blue analogs [3–6]. In recent years, significant efforts have been made to quest the synthesis of NVOPF cathode materials for SIBs, of which the high-temperature solid-phase method, the hydrothermal/solvothermal method, and low-temperature synthesized methods categorize the preparation [7]. High-temperature sintering-induced energy consumption, high alkali content, and exhaust gas inevitably increase the manufacturing costs [8]. Another issue is also inevitable to encounter the latent hazards with high temperature and pressure when hydrothermal/solvothermal processes are performed, as well as high equipment costs and low output [9]. By comparison, low-temperature synthesized methods can make a short-process and high-yield synthesis for NVOPF cathode materials with controllable morphology, high tap density, and good fluidity [10,11]. For example, Qi et al. successfully synthesized multi-level layered NVOPF microspheres in aqueous solution using soft templates within 6 days [12]. Zhang et al. utilized the concentration of 0.07 mol L−1 to prepare the monodisperse and uniform NVOPF cubic particles (∼800 nm) in a room-temperature aqueous solution [13]. However, the long duration and low concentration will hinder the utilization of space and equipment, leading to reduced productivity. Herein, a successfully aqueous-synthesized NVOPF was prepared through a creative co-precipitation method with a high concentration salt solution of 1.5 mol L−1 and a short duration of 2.5 h. Up to now, breaking through the limitations of aqueous-synthesized NVOPF has been made by ion-doping and surface morphology modifications to improve sodium storage performance [14–18]. But it is often ignored that there are characteristic ions in solution, including H3O+ and NH4 +, because these featured ions from dissolved raw materials are inevitably input into the targeted product during the preparation in solution, as shown in Fig. 1 . However, few studies pay attention to the potential heterogeneous cations staying in the lattice of materials, as well as their effects and removal. In this work, the deduction on the introduction of hydroxonium ion (H3O+) and ammonium ion (NH4 +) into the lattice of NVOPF materials has been revealed for the first time under the effect of electrostatic interactions between cations and electronegative oxygen atoms in the V=O and V–O–P groups. Such an effect triggers the competitive occupation with Na+ and the induction of the local electron atmosphere of the transition metal (V) atom, leading to the deteriorated redox process and the irreversible Na+ insertion/de-insertion. On this basis, the facile strategy of heat treatment-removed electrostatic interactions is proposed to remove the undesirable NH4 +/H3O+ and significantly improve the dilemma of low-capacity and high-voltage hysteresis. With this treatment under 300 °C, both the initial discharge capacity and the discharge voltage plateau of the NVOPF||Na cell can be enhanced effectively. This cell enables durable and stable cycling, as well as elevated rate performance and ionic kinetics. This discovery not only provides new insights into the material preparation in the water phase but also highlights the post-treatment as an unexplored and suitable tool. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 H3O+/NH4 + incorporation mechanism and post-treatment optimization Na3(VOPO4)2F cathode material was synthesized by an aqueous co-precipitation method involving ammonium fluoride (NH4F), vanadyl sulfate (VOSO4), sodium dihydrogen phosphate (NaH2PO4), and ammonium hydroxide (NH3·H2O) (Fig. 1a). During the mixture of VOSO4, NaH2PO4, NH4F, and NH3·H2O solutions, the pH value of whole system is maintained at 4.70. At the moment, the cationic VO2+ tends to adsorb the anionic OH− at the L position and forms VOOH+ and (VOOH)2 2+ [19], while the phosphate ions mainly exist in the form of HPO4 2− and H2PO4 − [20]. Based on the neutralization between the hydroxide ion (OH−) at the L position of VO2+ and hydrion (H+) in HPO4 2− or H2PO4 −, the V–O–P bond is set up accompanying the release of H2O (Fig. 1b). Further, affected by the di-complexation of F− ion, the two VOPO4 − ions connect in series to create the basic skeleton of NVOPF materials, namely [(VOPO4)2F]3−. The O atoms in V=O and P–O groups enriched with the electronegative charge in this skeleton should make an electrostatic interaction with the positive-charge species (e.g. Na+, NH4 +, and H3O+ ions). In this way, H3O+/NH4 + is going to occupy the adjacent vacancy of active Na+, thereby interfering with the subsequent Na+ insertion/de-insertion upon the repeated charge/discharge process (Fig. 1c), as shown in the electrochemical cycling later. According to the inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) test results (Table S1), the calculated Na/V atomic ratio is 1.498, which is lower than the theoretical value (1.5). This indicates that the NVOPF synthesized by the aqueous co-precipitation method has a sodium-deficient structure, and its structural formula should be Na3− x (NH4 +/H3O+) x (VOP4)2F. Most especially, these incorporated hetero-cations are difficult to remove by the ordinary vacuum drying and washing with NaCl solution and deionized water. Additionally, a theoretical analysis using density functional theory (DFT) was performed to investigate whether NH4 +/H3O+ could be incorporated into the NVOPF lattice. Fig. 1(d) presents three bulk structures: Na12V8P8O40F4, Na11NH4V8P8O40F4, and Na11H3OV8P8O40F4, with their optimized structural energies being −498.32, −518.58, and −512.85 eV, respectively. The structural energies were converted into bulk Gibbs free energies via G = E + G(T). Subsequently, free energy differences among the three structures were calculated based on the limiting ion concentrations under experimental conditions (Tables S2 and S3). As shown in Fig. 1(e), during the co-precipitation stage, the free energy differences for NH4 + and H3O+ incorporated into Na12V8P8O40F4 are −0.102 and −0.433 kJ mol−1, respectively; in the maturation stage, these values are 0.290 and 19.65 kJ mol−1. This reveals that the embedding of NH4 +/H3O+ is thermodynamically favorable during co-precipitation. The NVOPF system spontaneously combines with these cations to reduce free energy, consistent with the synthesis mechanism. To address this, the annealing post-treatment under an argon atmosphere at 300 °C has been proposed to eliminate the detrimental NH4 +/H3O+ ions so as to strengthen the electrochemical Na+-storage performance of the NVOPF cathode material. As shown in the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns and refined results in Fig. 2 (a), the aqueous-synthesized NVOPF sample possesses the tetragonal Na3(VOPO4)2F structure with a space group of I4/mmm [21], and the low R-factor values (R wp = 7.888%) verify the feasibility of co-precipitation method. However, the 1H magic-angle spinning solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS-ssNMR) spectrum of the NVOPF sample shows the three pronounced peaks at δ = 3.4, 7.3, and 11.4 ppm apart from some rotational spinning sidebands, which are attributed to the chemical shifts of adsorbed water, H3O+, and NH4 +, respectively (Fig. 2b) [22]. Further, the three-dimensional (3D) reconstruction models from time of flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (TOF-SIMS) expose the existence of NH4 + and H3O+ ionic fragments in the NVOPF sample (Fig. 2c, Figs. S1 and S2). The uniform distribution of NHOP, OH2OP, NH2OP, and HOV fragments notarizes the potential interactions between NH4 +/H3O+ and O atoms (P–O and V=O groups). The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) reveals the NH4 +/H3O+ content in the NVOPF sample (Fig. 2d). It is found that the weight loss begins at 80 °C, corresponding to the removal of adsorbed water, which is similar to the conventional vacuum drying near 100 °C. In the whole procedure, the weight loss of as-synthesized NVOPF material is 5.8951%. Such a loss remains unchanged when the temperature rises to 500 °C, indicating the nonoccurrence of physical and chemical transformation after annealing at this temperature for NVOPF material. Therefore, the XRD patterns of the NVOPF samples after heat treatment at various temperatures are analyzed, and the calculated cell parameters based on the Rietveld refinement are shown in Fig. S3 and Tables S4–S8. Impressively, lattice parameters of NVOPF, NVOPF-200, NVOPF-400, and NVOPF-500 deviate significantly from the standard crystal structure. Such deviations indicate incomplete structural optimization or excessive structural distortion at other temperatures. In contrast, the lattice parameters of NVOPF-300 (close to the standard crystal structure: a = b = 6.381 Å, c = 10.665 Å, and V = 431.054 Å3) create an ideal ion transport pathway [13,17,23]. To further optimize the synthesis conditions, we fixed the temperature at 300 °C and explored the crystal structure of NVOPF under different heat-treatment durations (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 8 h), as shown in Fig. S4 and Tables S9–S13. During the process from 0 to 4 h, lattice parameters fluctuated significantly, indicating that the crystal structure was still adjusted and optimized. Notably, when the heat-treatment time reached 8 h, the lattice parameters became nearly identical to those at 4 h. This suggests that by 4 h, the crystal structure had achieved optimal stabilization (prolonging the treatment to 8 h no longer induced noticeable structural improvements). Moreover, the thermogravimetry differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) (Fig. 2e) indicates that the as-arranged post-treatment, annealing at 300 °C for 4 h, can prompt the formation of stable-structure NVOPF material with no more physical and chemical conversion, thus validating the optimality of the 300 °C-4 h heat-treatment condition. Finally, Fig. 2(f) demonstrates the changes of gas characteristic curves from 0 to 4 h at 300 °C as the retention time goes. It is apparent that there are the prior peaks emerge in the 300 °C-1 h and 300 °C-2 h samples, differing from others. By analytic judgments, it could be seen that the significant outflows of both N2 and O2 are detected accompanying the helium gas as the carrier for 300 °C-0 h sample heating from room temperature to 300 °C (Fig. S5). The present N/O species makes us reasonably believe that the conversion of NH4 +/H3O+ ions in the crystal lattice takes place under the catalysis of vanadium-based compounds [24,25]. When the treatment time exceeds 4 h, no obvious signals of N2 and O2 are observed, indicating nearly complete removal during heat treatment. After heat treatment, the color of the NVOPF sample changes from turquoise to greenish (Fig. S6). The prepared NVOPF material, as observed by field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM), sustains a porous spherical particle with a size of approximately 17 μm, which is derived from the agglomeration of nanoscale irregular primary (Fig. 2g). Surprisingly, no cracks and dispersals appear in the NVOPF-300 material after the gas release (Fig. 2h), and it displays a pore-rich structure, such as micropores and mesopores, as well as a particular specific surface area of 14.98 m2 g−1 that differs from that of NVOPF sample (Fig. S7). Such an ample structure can facilitate the penetration of electrolytes and provide a short-range pathway for Na+ diffusion, thereby enhancing the storage performance for NVOPF cathode material. Moreover, the legible outline and distinct lattice fringe observed after magnification by transmission electron microscope (TEM) in the NVOPF sample indicate that the measured crystal plane corresponds to (002). After going through fast Fourier transform (FFT) and inverse fast Fourier transform (IFFT), the lattice spacing of this crystal plane is measured to be 0.536 nm (Fig. 2i). By contrast, the NVOPF-300 sample has a relatively blurred contour and shimmering lattice fringes, with the lattice spacing of the (002) plane reduced to 0.528 nm (Fig. 2j). The result is consistent with the (002) peak shifting to the right (Fig. S8). A decrease in the c-axis and the fading of nitrogen in the energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) element mapping (Fig. S9) are closely associated with the conversion of NH4 +/H3O+ and gas evolution. 2.2 Heat treatment-driven changes in chemical surroundings In order to clearly evaluate the persistent interaction between NH4 +/H3O+ and oxygen atoms and their removal from bulk NVOPF material, multiple characterizations have been employed (Fig. 3 ). Firstly, at low Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) wavenumber range, the peaks at 552.4, 669.2, and 911.8 cm−1 corresponding to the P–O bond symmetric stretching vibration (vss ), the P–O bond bending vibration (vb ), and the vibration of V=O bond [26], respectively, are detected for both NVOPF and NVOPF-300 samples (Fig. 3a). Besides, the extra bands at 531.4, 634.0, and 884.7 cm−1 emerge in the spectrum of NVOPF sample, which matches with the modulated vibration of P–O and V=O bond by the electrostatic interactions from hydrogen with its oxygen (OP–O and OV=O) [27–29]. In addition, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to examine the chemical states of the Na, V, P, O, F, N, and C elements at various temperatures (Fig. S10). The N 1s spectra reveal the significant lattice incorporation of NH4 + cation into NVOPF materials, and N only remains in the form of adsorbed NH3 on the surface after heat treatment (Fig. 3b) [30]. The O 1s spectra referring to three peaks (V=O, V–O–P, and O–H species) also reveal the change of binding energy of V=O/V–O–P species and the removement of H3O+ ion (Fig. 3c). It was found that the peak indicating O–H at 532.90 eV decreased from 11% to 2.7% after heat treatment. Correspondingly, the V4+ 2p binding energy increases from 517.0 to 517.1 eV with the increased temperature to 300 °C in the V 2p spectra (Fig. 3d), indicative of the enhanced stability of the [VO5F] octahedral structure during heat treatment. Finally, the N 1s, F 1s, and V 2p spectra of the NVOPF-500 sample highlight the importance of a suitable temperature for heat treatment to achieve effective removal of NH4 +/H3O+ (Fig. S11). These results mechanistically reveal electrostatic interactions between electronegative oxygen and hydrogen that come from NH4 +/H3O+ and its removal effect under heat treatment. X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray adsorption fine structure (EXAFS) tests were further conducted to achieve the precise analysis for the subtle evolution of local atomic coordination environment and electronic structure. As shown in Fig. 3(e), the V K-edge XANES spectra show a shift toward the lower energy for the absorption edge after heat treatment, indicating a decrease in the oxidation state of vanadium and the change of local coordination environment in the [VO5F] octahedron. Further, through Fourier transform (FT), the as-obtained R-space also reveals this change due to its better sensitivity to local coordination. By comparison with NVOPF, the V–O bond in the first shell layer for NVOPF-300 demonstrates a more stretched state, while the shrunken V–F bond in the second shell layer is observed (Fig. 3f and Fig. S12). Furthermore, the higher scattering intensities in the first and second shell layers of NVOPF-300 are detected from R- and K-space than those of NVOPF (Fig. S13), which shows that the coordination number of V–O and V–F increases from 4.06 and 1.00 to 4.68 and 1.2, relatively (Table S14). The results of V K-edge EXAFS k 3-weighted wavelet transform (WT) also display the alterations in the local coordination structure of V–O and V–F–V bonds (Fig. 3g). Particularly, the asymptotic shift from 5 Å−1 in NVOPF to 2.8 Å−1 in NVOPF-300 for the V–O bond happens, highlighting the formation of local coordination environments more concentrated for V redox and then achieving the high-capacity cathode materials. Such subtle change can be reflected on the 23Na-ssNMR. As shown in Fig. 3(h), the Na+–O–V4+ up-field shift of approximately 4.08 ppm is observed after heat treatment, emphasizing the regulated Na+ transportation. The 19F-ssNMR shows no difference in chemical shifts before and after heat treatment (Fig. S14), suggesting the stable di-coordination of fluorine with V atoms in the two octahedral [VO5F]. These differences directly or indirectly uncover the eliminated electrostatic interactions between NH4 +/H3O+ and lattice oxygen from heat treatment. 2.3 Electrochemical improvements and Na+-storage mechanism The removal of heterogeneous cations is potential to affect the structural stability and kinetic characteristics of cathode materials, as demonstrated by in-situ structural characterization and electrochemical tests. As shown in Fig. 4 (a, b), in situ XRD patterns reveal the transformation of crystal structure during Na+ sodiation/desodiation processes. Noted that the changes in the (200), (103), and (202) crystal planes are of particular interest. During the charging process, the diffraction peak of the (200) crystal plane is located at 27.9° initially, which gradually moves to a higher angle and finally fuses with the diffraction peak of (103) crystal plane that is located at 28.8° and shifts left to a lower angle of 28.3°. Similar changes are also observed in the other two pairs of diffraction peaks between (220) and (213) planes, as well as (301) and (105) planes. By comparison, the shift value of the (202) diffraction peak during charging/discharging for the NVOPF-300 sample is lower than that for the NVOPF, showing better stability. Fig. 4(c, d) displays the evolution of the lattice parameters (e.g. a and V) during charging and discharging. Upon the Na+ insertion/de-insertion, the parameter a of NVOPF-300 is almost restored to its original state, while the NVOPF can only provide a greatly reduced value in a (Fig. 4c), which associates with the space contraction after the decomposition and the release of NH4 +/H3O+ that are competitive with Na+ for coordination. Such decomposition can be verified by the analysis of in-situ differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) and the different interfacial features based on the variable temperature electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests of half-cell (Figs. S15 and S16). Further, the calculated change rate of cell volume (V) is 5.77% in the NVOPF sample, more than twice the rate of NVOPF-300 (2.76%) (Fig. 4d), which significantly demonstrates the enhanced structural stability after heat treatment. Such a stability can be further confirmed by the reversibility from cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves (Fig. S17). Next, the CV curves at different scan rates were collected to analyze the difference of Na+ diffusion for NVOPF and NVOPF-300 cathodes. It was found that the obvious oxidation peaks appear at around 3.8 and 4.1 V, while the corresponding reduction peaks also appear at around 3.5 and 3.9 V (Fig. S18a, b). At low-potential region, the cell using NVOPF-300 splits the reduction peak into two small peaks, i.e. R1 at 3.5 V and R3 at 3.35 V, at various scan rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 0.8, 1.0, and 1.2 mV s−1. This similar phenomenon also occurs in the NVOPF system at the rate 0.2 and 0.5 mV s−1. These suggest that Na+ ions are embedded into two different lattice positions for NVOPF-300 cathode material [31], which associates with an incremental freedom degree of Na+ in lattice after removing the NH4 +/H3O+ cations. After fitting, the calculated results suggest that at the discharge stage, NVOPF-300 shows the higher D Na + (20.78 × 10−12 cm2 s−1 for R1 and 9.10 × 10−12 cm2 s−1 for R2) than NVPOF (9.14 × 10−12 and 2.84 × 10−12 cm2 s−1) (Fig. 4e and Fig. S18c, d). Notably, during the charging process, NVOPF exhibits higher D Na +than NVOPF-300 due to the structural support provided by NH4 +/H3O+ cations in the open-circuit voltage (OCV) state. These cations expand the lattice spacing and then create wider Na+ transport channels (Fig. S3e). However, during charging, the decomposition of NH4 +/H3O+ ions induces lattice contraction and channel damage (Fig. S16), thereby reducing the Na+ diffusion capacity. After 2 cycles, the NVOPF-300 delivers a higher D Na + than NVOPF in galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) measurements at either charging or discharging process (Fig. 4f and Fig. S19). This difference probably results from the harmful electrochemical activation toward the residual heterogeneous cations in the NVOPF sample, leading to gas evolution that coincides with DEMS measurements and in-situ XRD analysis. Further, the variable-temperature EIS after 2 cycles was carried out to explore the energy barrier for Na+ diffusion (Fig. 4g and Fig. S20). The high charge transfer impedance (R ct) at low frequency region is held in the cell with NVOPF cathode, more than 100 Ω, which keeps almost unchanged with the increasing temperature. After treatment, the R ct values in the cell with NVOPF-300 cathode express a gradual-decrease direction, and both of them are inferior to the level of 100 Ω. Moreover, the fitting activation energy shows the values of 39.93 and 32.80 kJ mol−1 for the cell with NVOPF and NVOPF-300 cathodes, respectively. Apparently, these results confirm that the removal of heterogeneous cations facilitates the Na+ diffusion kinetics. After the elaboration on the weakened electrostatic interaction from heat treatment, the developed cathode material NVOPF-300 was expected to enhance the Na+-storage performance. Fig. 5 (a) displayed the first-cycle galvanostatic charge and discharge (GCD) curves of NVOPF and NVOPF-300 at a rate of 0.1 C (1 C = 130 mA g−1). The first GCD curve shows two voltage plateaus at 3.6 and 4.0 V, consistent with the CV curve that indexes the successive insertion/extraction for Na+ (Fig. S16). In the discharge region, it is obvious that the voltage hysteresis in the cell with NVOPF cathode contributes to the low discharge capacity of 123.0 mAh g−1 and initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 82.2%. By contrast, the cell with NVOPF-300 cathode holds the placid plateaus without hysteresis and provides a high capacity of 126 mAh g−1 and ICE (86.8%). On the side, the cells with NVOPF after heat treatment at different temperatures can deliver a higher capacity and ICE than the cell with NVOPF without heat treatment (Fig. S21a). These results suggest the importance of heat treatment and its enhanced electrochemical improvements. In the rate performance tests (Fig. 5b), the NVOPF-300 cathode shows the better rate capacity as compared with NVOPF material, whose discharge capacities are about 125, 128, 127, 126, 122, 118, 107, and 99 mAh g−1 at different rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 5.0, 10.0, and 20.0 C, respectively. Also, a reversible capacity of 127.0 mAh g−1 can be recovered when the rate is restored to 0.1 C rate, which suggests its good rate performance, as further confirmed by the charge/discharge curves at different rates (Fig. S22a, b). To highlight the exceptional performance of NVOPF-300 cathode, the NVOPF||Na cells with the treated NVOPF cathode at 200, 400, and 500 °C were compared in Fig. S21. It is well known that the energy density of battery is determined by the specific discharge capacity of material and the output voltage is connected with voltage plateau of cathode material [32,33]. The average discharge voltage at different rates was recorded in Fig. S22(c). The discharge voltage of the cell with NVOPF-300 approximately ranges from 3.5 to 3.86 V at the rate range of 0.1–20 C, notably higher than that in the cell with NVOPF, which illustrates the higher energy density of NVOPF-300 cathode materials. Furthermore, the half-cell with NVOPF-300 cathode also demonstrates the better long-term cycling stability at 1 C (Fig. 5d). The NVOPF-300||Na cell exhibits impressive initial capacity of 129.22 mAh g−1 and maintains the reversible capacity of 121.18 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles corresponding to the capacity retention of 93.7% and a high average coulombic efficiency (CE) of 99.8%. These cyclic capacities are much superior to 119 mAh g−1 of the NVOPF||Na cell. Noted that the tangled points in capacity and coulombic efficiency appear, which are attributed to the disturbance of impurities in material lattice. This implies that the optimization of material structure and performances still remains possible. Remarkably, even at a high current density of 20 C, the cell with NVOPF-300 cathode has a reversible discharge specific capacity of 75.6 mAh g−1 after 3500 cycles, which is approximately 76.5% of the initial capacity. Under this retention, only 2500 cycles can be acquired in the NVOPF||Na cell. These selected charge/discharge curves further confirm the superiority in the NVOPF-300 system (Fig. S23). Moreover, the electrochemical properties of the half-cells were also measured at high/low temperatures to assess the feasibility of as-designed cathode materials. At a high temperature of 60 °C, the cell with NVOPF and NVOPF-300 cathode shows the discharge specific capacities of 122.19 and 129.7 mAh g−1 at 1 C, respectively (Fig. 5f). After 350 cycles, the capacity of 123.13 mAh g−1 remains in the latter while the former keeps a slight-low capacity, which is further confirmed by the selected charge/discharger curves (Fig. S24a, b). When the temperature is switched to −20 °C, the cell with NVOPF-300 cathode can still release a specific capacity of 120 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C, outdistancing that of the counterpart (78.2 mAh g−1). A lower voltage hysteresis for the plateau appearing at 3.4 V is also observed (Fig. S24c, d). Within 50 cycles at 0.5 C, NVOPF-300 cathode can endow the half-cell with the retention as high as 95.5% and a final specific capacity of 88.2 mAh g−1 (Fig. 5g), superior to the NVOPF||Na cell with the gradual capacity decay to zero. Comparing with these recently reported, the NVOPF-300||Na half-cell has a high energy density over 500 Wh kg−1 (calculated by weight of cathode materials) at 1 C rate, which is at the advanced level for this class of material (Fig. 5c) [10,12,13,15,17,23,34–40]. Additionally, we have systematically collated and conducted a comparative analysis on the researches about the low-temperature NVOPF synthesis (Table S15). By comparison, our research demonstrates the advantages of material preparation such as shorter process and higher yield. 2.4 NVOPF-300||HC full cells To demonstrate the practical applications of as-designed NVOPF-300 cathode materials, the commercial hard carbon (HC) was used as the anode to assemble the NVOPF-300||HC full-cell (Fig. 6 a). To avoid the impact of the anode, the commercial HC electrodes were assembled with sodium metal and tested between 0 and 2 V (vs. Na/Na+) to form a stable interface and realize pre-sodiation (Fig. S25). The full-cell maintains two plateau voltages of 3.3 and 3.8 V between 2.0 and 4.3 V at 0.1 C (1 C = 130 mA g−1), delivering a reversible specific capacity of 128.52 mAh g−1 (Fig. 6b). Fig. 6(c) shows the rate capacity of the NVOPF-300||HC full-cell at various rates. The full cells achieve the discharge capacities as high as 131.36 and 109.36 mAh g−1 at 0.2 and 10 C rates, respectively, which correspond to impressive energy density of 480 and 349 Wh kg−1. Furthermore, a long cycling stability over 1000 cycles is harvested in the NVOPF-300||HC full-cell at 3 C rate (Fig. 6d), accompanied with a high discharge capacity of 119.4 mAh g−1 at the end and a CE approaching 100%. These are corresponsive to 97.5% capacity retention, about a proud capacity decay rate of 0.0025% per cycle. Such superior performances can be further confirmed by the selective charging/discharging curves at various rates and 3 C for cycling (Fig. S26), demonstrating the feasible applications of as-synthesized NVOPF-300 cathode. It is noteworthy that the performance of assembled NVOPF-300||HC full-cell in this work can be up to an advanced level in terms of energy/power density in contrast to these recently reported works (calculated by weight of cathode materials) (Fig. 6e) [14,23,41,42]. 3 Conclusions In summary, we have elaborated the aqueous co-precipitation mechanism for NVOPF synthesis and the incorporation of heterogeneous NH4 +/H3O+ cations into material lattice, combined with physical characterizations. It is found that NH4 +/H3O+ cations are able to occupy the free space around Na+ and form competitive coordination in the form of electrostatic attraction, resulting in the subsequent decomposition of gaseous impurity and the blocking of Na+ diffusion, thereby deteriorating the performance of NVOPF cathode. Consequently, a facile heat treatment under optimal conditions of 300 °C for 4 h has been successfully developed to remove this detrimental heterogeneous NH4 +/H3O+ cations from the bulk. With this operation, the as-prepared NVOPF-300 material can contribute to the higher voltage plateau and discharge capacity. The cell with NVOPF-300 cathode can stably cycle up to 1000 cycles with a high retention of 93.7% at 1 C rate, even sustaining a high capacity after 3500 cycles at 20 C, significantly superior to the contrast. Besides, it also performs well in the NVOPF-300||HC full-cell, showing the much-improved electrochemical performances. These results reveal the presence of heterogeneous cations in the material lattice and their roles, highlighting the importance of post treatment for their removal and providing novel sights into the aqueous synthesis of NVOPF cathode material for high-performance SIBs. coredata.dc:description: The aqueous preparation of Na3(VOPO4)2F cathode material with low cost and good structural stability has attracted extensive attention for advancing sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). However, the inclusive heterogeneous cations incorporated into the material lattice, dominated by coordination chemistry, are always overlooked. Herein, the embroiled NH4 +/H3O+ cations in the Na3(VOPO4)2F lattice have been first disclosed during aqueous co-precipitation. It involves the electrostatic interactions between hydrogen protons (NH4 +/H3O+) and electronegative oxygen atoms (V=O and V–O–P groups), which induces the terrible Na+-storage performance, as demonstrated by multiple characterizations. Followingly, the very-facile operation, i.e. heat treatment, has been raised to remove NH4 +/H3O+ cations and then achieved high-performance Na3(VOPO4)2F. Therefore, the Na3(VOPO4)2F||Na cell contributes to the significantly improved discharge capacity (129.7 mAh g−1) and voltage plateau from 3.63 to 3.87 V (vs. Na/Na+) at 0.2 C. The ultrahigh capacity retentions of 93.7% and 76.7% after 1000 and 3500 cycles at 1 and 20 C rates under 25 °C are harvested, respectively, as well as high/low-temperature performances and rate capability. Eventually, the as-assembled Na3(VOPO4)2F||hard carbon full-cell delivers excellent long-term cycling stability over 1000 cycles with 97.5% retention at 3 C. These emphasize the high-efficacy synthesis of Na3(VOPO4)2F and provide insights into the aqueous co-precipitation for the development of materials used in SIBs.
